important.para:
The behavior of storage allocation is more conservative in 2.2.4 than in 2.1.7 and prior releases or 2.2.0-2.2.3. &PRODUCT; will no longer create volumes on primary storage resources that have a storage percentage used higher than that defined by storage.capacity.threshold
global configuration. Previously &PRODUCT; would allocate a primary storage resource up to 100% full. This space reservation is required as a fix to cases where snapshots of VMs could not be taken when the storage had been allocated to 100% full. The use of a threshold setting allows the administrator to reserve space for snapshots in progress for existing volumes. Deployments with primary storage that is close to full should examine the value of this parameter before upgrading. If all primary storage resources are more full than storage.capacity.threshold no new volumes can be created after upgrade.

row.entry: Bug
Description
KVM: VM live migration will work reliably
Space is reserved on each primary storage volume for snapshots.
Attempts to remove a host with running VMs will correctly fail.
Listing system VM IP addresses will distinguish link local from private IP addresses.
The service offering upgrade option is now always shown to users. Attempts to upgrade the service offering for a running VM will fail with a clear error message.
Login problems with Safari have been fixed.
Attach/detach of a data disk in a multi-cluster deployment will work correctly. Previously the data disk could be deleted.
ISOs that are not bootable may now be uploaded
KVM: Userdata and instance metadata now work correctly.
The guest network CIDR must be a RFC1918 address.
Port forwarding with the virtual router will now work with IP addresses from multiple VLANs
The VM's metered running time is now correct
IP address releases will not intermittently fail
XenServer: the network throttling values are now correctly applied
Windows password management scripts work correctly in the presence of external network elements
A security vulnerability that allowed download of some files from the console proxy VM has been fixed
End users are no longer allowed access to the console of their virtual router
Security groups are no longer present in the UI in Advanced Networking zones
Performance of the listVirtualMachines API cal in the presence of many VMs has been significantly improved.
A security issue that could allow end users to snapshot another user's volume has been fixed
XenServer: a stop VM request will forcefully stop the VM even if qemu has crashed on the XenServer host
Host tagging now works correctly
Usage clients have a path to determining the OS type of a guest booted from a blank VM.
KVM: HA failover works correctly with OCFS2.
Users may again create four parallel snapshot schedules
XenServer: local storage now works correctly
CPU over-provisioning now works correctly
Zone delete now works correctly
Cluster delete now works correctly.
Many
Several bugs around resource limit tracking have been fixed.
Firefox 4 and IE 9 are supported browsers
Bug
Description
Network throttling may be disabled altogether.
The listTemplates API call will return an md5sum of the template.
Virtual machines may be manually live-migrated by the administrator. The administrator may pick a VM and the host that the VM should be placed on.
A network may be dedicated to a domain. Only users in that domain and its children will have access to the network.
The global configuration parameter default.page.limit has been added. This sets the maximum number of results that will be returned by list* API calls. Default is 500.
The UI has been changed to provide clearer monitoring of snapshot progress.
The Java process's heap sizeJava has been increased from 28 MB to 1024 MB
